info.game_comments:
Ken Jennings game 30.

Ken breaks the $1 million mark.

(1, 1).clue: Dating from around 300 B.C., the silver tetradrachma coin depicts this Macedonian leader

(2, 1).clue: Gary Oldman hijacks the President's plane in this 1997 thriller

(3, 1).clue: This, an orzel in Poland, is seen on some of our coins

(4, 1).clue: A young reporter may have to work in this section updating life stories, just in case

(5, 1).clue: Among this famous literary detective's exploits is the "Adventure of the Devil's Foot"

(6, 1).clue: Admiral Chester Nimitz formed this group during World War II to showcase Naval aviation

(1, 2).clue: Following the lead of Germany, this man declared war on Britain & France in June 1940

(2, 2).clue: A crop-dusting plane nearly makes dust out of Cary Grant in this Hitchcock thriller

(3, 2).clue: In Swahili, this familiar sight in the Sahara is a ngamia

(4, 2).clue: An uncritical piece is called this & is as hard-hitting as the pastry of the same name

(5, 2).clue: Tartini's sonata "The Devil's Trill" came to him in a dream in which the devil played this stringed instrument

(6, 2).clue: One of the bestselling paperbacks of 2003 was "Angels and Demons" by this author of "The Da Vinci Code"

(1, 3).clue: In 2002 Helen Clark won election to a second term as this Down Under country's prime minister

(2, 3).clue: William Wellman, who'd served in the Lafayette Escadrille Flying Corps, directed this first Best Picture winner

(3, 3).clue: In Dijon a homard is a lobster & a canard is one of these (if someone throws a homard at you, canard)

(4, 3).clue: It's the 7-letter term for the text under the photo that goes with the article; it can be a quote from the story

(5, 3).clue: One of this "Robinson Crusoe" author's final works was "The Political History of the Devil"

(6, 3).clue: No Goofy or Mickey Mouse players on the Anaheim Angels, even though it was owned by this company until 2003

(1, 4).clue: It's the military rank of the head of state of Libya

(2, 4).clue: Bruce Willis is waiting for his wife's plane to land at Dulles when trouble begins in this 1990 sequel

(3, 4).clue: As Lowe is German for this animal, it sounds like Loews cinemas should only show MGM movies

(4, 4).clue: These freelance reporters not completely "tied" to the paper but working part-time were once paid by the column inch

(5, 4).clue: Goethe & Mann used an anonymous 1587 tale about this devilish doctor as a basis for tales of their own

(6, 4).clue: In 1997 this company introduced its Angels line of lingerie

(1, 5).clue: A former foreign minister, Fernando Cardoso became president of this large South American country in 1995

(2, 5).clue: The Jailbird is the prisoner transport plane in this 1997 Nicolas Cage flick

(3, 5).clue: You'll find atum, this fish, sandwiched inside Portuguese dictionaries

(4, 5).clue: These 2 "line"s tell readers where & when a story originated & who wrote it

(5, 5).clue: In a Stephen Vincent Benet work, this man defends Jabez Stone before the devil's jury of villains

(6, 5).clue: The natural feature called Salto Angel in Spanish is the world's highest uninterrupted one of these

(1, 1).clue: The 16th century Corsairs of northern Africa were known collectively as these pirates

(2, 1).clue: In 2001 she played Annie Oakley in a Broadway revival of "Annie Get Your Gun"; she now stars in her own sitcom on the WB

(4, 1).clue: Find out if Great Aunt Agatha was really a spy when you take up this hobby, the study of family lineage

(5, 1).clue: 2 past presidents of the National Education Association lead an effort to reduce this to improve learning

(6, 1).clue: On this 1970s TV series, a private investigator has his office in the Desert Inn

(1, 2).clue: Group in the '60s who were the first "S" in the SDS

(2, 2).clue: (Hi, I'm Mark Wills.) In my hit, "Nineteen Something", I sang, "My first love was" this 'Dukes of Hazzard' character "in them cut off jeans"

(4, 2).clue: People who study & collect these like to call themselves conchologists

(5, 2).clue: This government program for preschoolers began as a summer project in LBJ's War on Poverty

(6, 2).clue: The National Center for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder falls under the scope of this U.S. Govt. department

(1, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew displays some artifacts at the Nat'l Constitution Center in Philadelphia, PA.) Now National Archives properties, the Watergate tools were used by members of this committee, known as CREEP
(1, 3).correct response: the Committee to Re-Elect the President

(2, 3).clue: In 2003 this late great entertainer won 3 CMA Awards, including single of the year for "Hurt"

(4, 3).clue: This show that was just 7 minutes long when it debuted in 1994 has inspired many to take up Irish step-dancing

(5, 3).clue: This university leads the U.S. in the market value of its endowment assets; Yale is No. 2

(6, 3).clue: Forced into exile in 1955, Emperor Bao Dai was this country's last ruling monarch

(1, 4).clue: The Jacobins were a party in France in 1789; 100 years earlier the Jacobites were supporters of this family in England

(2, 4).clue: (Hi. I'm Lorrie Morgan.) In a 1993 hit I asked, "What part of" this "don't you understand, to put it plain and simple I'm not into one night stands"

(4, 4).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew sticks a flower step in a shallow pot.)  Moribana is a natural style of this timeless Japanese art of flower arranging

(5, 4).clue: This numerical portion of the Education Amendments of 1972 prohibited sex discrimination in athletics

(6, 4).clue: During the 5th century, this Teutonic tribe conquered part of North Africa & ruled there for 100 years

(1, 5).clue: Term for the natives of India who served in the British army; they mutinied in 1857

(2, 5).clue: Toby Keith & this country great recently served up a hit called "Beer For My Horses"

(4, 5).clue: You might become a "wrap artist"--not like Coolio, but like this man who wrapped the Reichstag in fabric

(5, 5).clue: Richard W. Riley, who served under this president, is the only Secretary of Education to serve a full 8 years

(6, 5).clue: Named for the British logician who created it, it's a representational diagram of sets

(0, 0).clue: The first 2 New York Times headlines set in 96-point type were in these 2 years, 5 years apart
